poem:
Title: In an Era of Cauliflower Neighbourhoods

In the blue-and-white of Netherlands' dawn,
Awakens Delft, in Tanthof born.
A hundred souls 'neath single roof unite,
Their slumbers spun in gossiped light.

Low-rise, no-grid patterns here lend grace,
To human life in crowded space.
Neither tower high, nor gridlock's pain,
Just cauliflow'r schemes in town-planner's brain. 

In each shared breath, a story blooms,
Strung together in shared sleep rooms.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘People always gossiped about our sleeping arrangements!’ How 100 people share a happy home in the Netherlands I meet Konstanze Winter in Delft, a canal-encircled city in the Netherlands best known for its distinctive blue-and-white pottery. We are in the Tanthof quarter, one of the Netherlands’ so-called “cauliflower neighbourhoods” beloved of 1970s town planners. These were conceived as an antidote to the rigid grid layouts and tower blocks of the era, featuring low-rise architecture and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
